posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If you play Aielund with EMS there are several changes to the Bard class:

You get Weapon Proficiency Rogue.

You get 6 skill points per level + int bonus (x4 at lvl 1)

You have the following extra spells to choose from:
Acid Splash as C0
Banishment as C5
Deafening Clang as C1
Dominate Monster as C6
Electric Jolt as C0
Endurance as C2
Endure Elements as C1
Freedom Of Movement as C4
Great Thunderclap as C5
Greater Shadow Conjuration as C5
Horizikaul's Boom as C1
Mass Charm as C6
Protection From Elements as C3
Ray Of Frost as C0
Resist Elements as C2
Shadow Conjuration as C4
Shield as C1
Stoneskin as C4

The Bard song and Curse song  are changed:
Perform requirement is Bard-level +3 for each song ( 4 for lvl 1 song, 5 for level 2 song etc)
Every 6 levels starting at Bard 1: +1 AB, +1 Damage (Bard 1, 7, 13, 19, 25 etc)
Every 6 levels starting at Bard 2: +1 DodgeAC  (Bard 2, 8, 14, 20, 26 etc)
Every 6 levels starting at Bard 3: +1 Fort
Every 6 levels starting at Bard 4: +1 Will
Every 6 levels starting at Bard 5: +1 Reflex
Every 6 levels starting at Bard 6: +1 Skills, +6 HP
There is no level 30 song cap

At lvl 16 the bonus is: +3 AB, +3 Damage, +3 AC, +3 Fort, +3 Will, +2 Refl, +2 skills, +12 HP, and there is not a clearly defined "Sweet spot" at lvl 16 anymore.

Lasting Impression is only 2x normal song duration (i.e. 20 rounds)

posts.author: i300
posts.content:
Wow, pity... those are some interesting changes to Bard in EMS, but aside from a small handful of spells which were solid, simple changes (for which I've extracted the .ncs files for into the override folder) I've decided to give that component a wide berth on my install of Aielund after a closer examination of the readme file and actually looking up the tabletop source material. In a nutshell, it's all over the place; some changes are understandable, but others are from a wild mix of 3.0e (which NWN1 was based on), 3.5e, and some random changes that follow neither editions nor bioware's implementation (intended or otherwise) and imo have little justification. I'm sure the author had his reasons, but the overall tone/philosophy that's conveyed by his notes combined with the fact his documentation at times is inaccurate or misleading ('per PHB' even though it's clearly not the case at times) was rather offputting.

Thanks for the welcome Stagmeister; I did see the barb/bard/CoT thread and was intrigued, but in the end decided I'd prefer fighter for WS/EWS. I also like having as feats as possible/varied tactical options to represent a smart, skilled fighter vs pure brute force, part of the reason I'm not fond of RDD builds (aside from having developed a distaste for them from seeing scores of of min/max RDD clones running around PWs). The F6/Bard16/CoT sounds promising. Are there any specific builds here I've missed or do you have something in mind?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
i300 wrote: Btw, I've seen some Aielund melee builds (such as Empyre's Katana builds weaponmaster-for-campaigns-t2354938.html) that seem to completely ignore Concentration; there's definitely quite a bit of taunting going on by foes in ch.1 at least - is there a reason people are dropping Concentration? Seems like such a glaring oversight I'm wondering if Aielund features boatloads (there's definitely an overabundance of magical items which unfortunately is typical of CRPGs imo) of magic item with immunity to taunt that's loaded with too many goodies to pass up or some such?
The problem isn't so much an oversight as a question of priorities. You need to be maxing Discipline, Tumble (40 unmodified ranks), UMD (where possible - certainly up to a modified 33), and a perception skill (Listen or Spot). That's about 160 points. Then, for a Bard, you need some Perform for the song, so you're up around 175/180 points. It's rare to have a melee build with many more than 200/220 points, so it becomes a contest between Concentration and Spellcraft (and maybe Taunt if classes permit), both of which have their merits. In Empyre's particular build, you need to use 8 points to get the 4 Intimidate required for WM as well. Craft Weapon has a particular use in Aielund, too, so there's not much scope left. In a CoT build, rather than a WM one, you're going to have much better saves, so the lure of Spellcraft is lessened somewhat, but is still hard to ignore. It's the old "you can't have everything you want," problem again.

Hope this helps.

EDIT: @ Valerfor - Looking forward to seeing the results of your endeavours!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
As per NWN rules and how the game engine checks if builds are legal, builds with classes of conflicting aligment are considered legal.
But to be able to build such builds without cheating, the mod (or a DM) must give alignment changes according to your character's actions.
Several PWs also have rules that prohibit certain class combinations, and Paladin/ Bard may easily end up on such a list.
